posts.author: InitiativeTracker
posts.content:
We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use build to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

For my next character, I want to focus on build as a central feature. What subclasses or multiclass options would work best with this?

Our table uses a house rule for build where we allow more flexibility in how it's applied. It's been working well so far.

In my campaign, we had a situation with build that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

posts.author: DungeonMasterDave
posts.content:
I've been playing a Tiefling Cleric in my campaign, and I've noticed that build really impacts how effective the character is in combat.

I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for build are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

How do other DMs balance encounters that involve build? I find it either makes combats too easy or too difficult.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about build. Based on my experience, it works differently.

posts.author: WarlocksWisdom
posts.content:
The best campaign moment I ever had involved creative use of build to solve what seemed like an impossible puzzle.

In the new 2024 rules update, they changed how build works. Now it's more streamlined but I'm not sure if it's better overall.

In our last session, we encountered a Owlbear and tried to use build to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.
